topic.title: Getting Started with Centralized Logging Service

body.p: A typical cloud consists of multiple servers which makes locating a specific log from a single server difficult. The Centralized Logging feature helps the administrator evaluate and troubleshoot the distributed cloud deployment from a single location.

section.title: New in
section.p:
The Logging API is a new component in the centralized logging architecture. It works between log producers and log storage. In most cases it works by default after installation with no additional configuration. To use Logging API with logging-as-a-service or with Helion Carrier Grade, you must configure an end-point. This component adds flexibility and supportability for features in the future. Do I need to Configure monasca-log-api? If you are only using Helion Lifecycle Manager (HLM), then the default configuration is ready to use. If you are using logging in any of the following deployments, then you will need to query Keystone to get an end-point to use.
Logging as a Service
Platform as a Service
Helion Carrier Grade The Logging API is protected by Keystoneâ€™s role-based access control. To ensure that logging is allowed and Monasca alarms can be triggered, the user must have the monasca-user role. To get an end-point from Keystone:
Log on to HLM (deployer node).
To list the Identity service catalog, run: source ./service.osrc openstack catalog list
In the output, find Kronos, and its region. For Example:
Name Type Endpoints
kronos region2 public: http://myhelion.test:5607/v3.0 admin: http://192.168.245.5:5607/v3.0 internal: http://192.168.245.5:5607/v3.0
Use the same port number as found in the output. In the example, you would use port 5607.

In the logging-ansible restart playbook has been updated to manage the start,stop, and restart of the Centralized Logging Service in a specific way. This change was made to ensure the proper stop, start, and restart of Elasticsearch. It is recommended that you only use the logging playbooks to perform the start, stop, and restart of the Centralized Logging Service. Manually mixing the start, stop, and restart operations with the logging playbooks will result in complex failures. For more information, see How Do I Stop and Start the Service?
